constructs.name: compulsive_context_switching
constructs.description: Frequency and intensity of involuntary shifting attention between tasks, apps, or activities despite intention to focus

constructs.name: urge_to_switch
constructs.description: Momentary craving or impulse to check something else, shift tasks, or seek new stimuli

constructs.name: task_engagement
constructs.description: Degree of absorption, flow, and sustained attention in current task

constructs.name: current_emotional_state
constructs.description: Present mood valence and arousal, including stress, anxiety, boredom, or frustration

constructs.name: physical_state
constructs.description: Bodily sensations including hunger, caffeine level, physical comfort, and restlessness

constructs.name: metacognitive_awareness
constructs.description: Real-time awareness of one's own attention state and switching behavior; mindfulness of when urges arise

constructs.name: impulse_control_capacity
constructs.description: Available self-regulation resources to resist impulses; executive function capacity that depletes through the day

constructs.name: cognitive_fatigue
constructs.description: Mental exhaustion and reduced cognitive resources from sustained effort or poor recovery

constructs.name: overall_stress_level
constructs.description: Background level of perceived stress from work, life demands, and unfinished tasks

constructs.name: social_connection_need
constructs.description: Craving for social interaction, validation, or fear of missing out on social information

constructs.name: habit_strength
constructs.description: Automaticity and entrenchment of context-switching as a behavioral pattern; reinforced through repetition

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Quality and quantity of sleep from the previous night

constructs.name: notification_exposure
constructs.description: Frequency and intrusiveness of external interruptions from devices, apps, and alerts

constructs.name: environmental_cues
constructs.description: Visual presence and accessibility of distracting devices, browser tabs, or applications

constructs.name: task_difficulty_skill_match
constructs.description: Whether current task difficulty matches skill level - optimal creates flow, mismatch causes boredom or overwhelm

constructs.name: task_intrinsic_interest
constructs.description: Inherent appeal and engaging qualities of the current task independent of external rewards

constructs.name: time_pressure
constructs.description: Perceived urgency and deadline pressure from pending commitments and obligations

constructs.name: trait_impulsivity
constructs.description: Dispositional tendency toward impulsive behavior and difficulty delaying gratification

constructs.name: novelty_seeking_tendency
constructs.description: Trait preference for new stimuli, variety, and stimulation

constructs.name: frustration_tolerance
constructs.description: Dispositional ability to persist through difficulty, boredom, and discomfort without escaping

edges.description: Strong urges to switch directly precipitate switching behavior when not inhibited
High engagement and flow states protect against switching; low engagement creates vulnerability
Awareness of urges and attention state enables conscious choice rather than automatic switching
Notifications can trigger automatic reflexive attention shifts bypassing deliberation
Negative emotions like anxiety, boredom, and frustration increase urge to escape into distraction
Negative emotional states impair concentration and reduce task absorption
Optimal challenge-skill balance creates flow; mismatch causes boredom or overwhelm
Inherently interesting tasks naturally capture and sustain attention
Boring tasks increase craving for more stimulating alternatives
Each notification creates a curiosity-driven urge to check and respond
Visible distractors like open tabs and nearby phone cue conditioned switching urges
Hunger, caffeine crashes, and discomfort worsen mood and increase irritability
Physical discomfort and restlessness reduce capacity for mindful attention
Mental exhaustion depletes self-regulation resources needed to resist urges
Chronic stress accelerates mental exhaustion and depletes cognitive resources
Deadline pressure and urgency contribute to elevated stress levels
Stress increases desire for social support and connection-seeking behavior
Poor sleep leads to impaired cognitive recovery and daytime fatigue
Sleep deprivation directly impairs prefrontal cortex function and self-control
Higher executive control capacity enables resisting switching urges
Low self-control capacity amplifies experienced urge intensity
Mental exhaustion reduces ability to maintain focus and enter flow states
Fatigue impairs meta-awareness and makes automatic behavior more likely
High background stress creates anxious irritable emotional baseline
Poor sleep increases negative affect, irritability, and emotional reactivity
Sleep quality affects physical energy, alertness, and bodily comfort
Unmet social needs create urges to check social media and communications
Strong habits make switching automatic, bypassing conscious deliberation
Entrenched habits create conditioned urges in response to environmental cues
Higher trait impulsivity means lower baseline capacity for impulse control
High novelty seekers experience stronger urges for new stimulation
Higher frustration tolerance enables sustained engagement through difficult or boring periods
Excessive switching leads to guilt, frustration, and self-criticism
Frequent switching depletes cognitive resources and accelerates fatigue
Switching reduces productivity, creating accumulated work and deadline pressure
Each switch reinforces the habitual pattern through neural pathway strengthening

indicators.name: topic_switches_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the number of times the browsing topic changes to a clearly unrelated subject within this hour. A topic switch occurs when consecutive searches/visits shift to unrelated content (e.g., from 'haskell programming' to 'restaurants sicily'). Count each distinct topic transition as 1.

indicators.name: search_frequency
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the total number of [search] entries within this hour. Each search query counts as 1 regardless of topic.

indicators.name: abandoned_visit_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count [visit] entries that are immediately followed by an unrelated action within 2 minutes (based on timestamps visible in this hour's data). These represent visits the user quickly abandoned. Each such visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: curiosity_driven_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches that appear exploratory or tangential - Wikipedia lookups on unrelated topics, random definition searches, curiosity questions that don't connect to the surrounding activity. Each such search counts as 1.

indicators.name: coherent_session_duration
indicators.how_to_measure: For each coherent topic cluster (consecutive entries on the same subject matter), calculate the duration in minutes from first to last entry timestamp. Record the duration for each cluster found in this hour.

indicators.name: topic_depth_entries
indicators.how_to_measure: For each coherent topic cluster (consecutive searches/visits on same subject), count the number of entries in that cluster. Record the count for each cluster found in this hour.

indicators.name: escape_behavior_presence
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if there are visits to entertainment/escape content (YouTube music/videos, Reddit browsing, games, memes) that interrupt work patterns. 0 if all activity appears purposeful or work-related.

indicators.name: restless_search_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches that appear restless or mood-driven - isolated searches that don't lead anywhere, entertainment lookups, music searches, or apparent procrastination searches. Each such search counts as 1.

indicators.name: food_drink_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or visits related to food, restaurants, cafes, coffee, snacks, hunger, meal planning, or food delivery. Each relevant entry counts as 1.

indicators.name: physical_need_indicator
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if any searches/visits relate to physical needs or discomfort (caffeine, stretching, health symptoms, tiredness, exercise, physical complaints). 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: productivity_tool_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or visits related to productivity, focus, attention management, or self-improvement (e.g., 'focus app', 'pomodoro', 'time management', 'stop procrastinating'). Each relevant entry counts as 1.

indicators.name: intentional_learning_depth
indicators.how_to_measure: Rate browsing intentionality on a 0-2 scale for this hour: 0 = reactive scattered browsing with no apparent purpose; 1 = mixed purposeful and distracted; 2 = clearly deliberate systematic learning (progression through documentation, tutorials, papers on same topic).

indicators.name: focused_entry_flag
indicators.how_to_measure: For each browsing entry in today's data, mark 1 if it is part of a coherent topic sequence (connected to adjacent entries on same topic), or 0 if it is isolated/scattered (unrelated to surrounding entries).

indicators.name: distraction_resistance_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances where a distraction site (Reddit, YouTube, social media) is visited briefly (1-2 entries) and the user returns to focused work-related activity. Each instance of resisted distraction counts as 1.

indicators.name: late_night_browsing
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if there is any browsing activity between 11pm and 5am in this day's data. 0 otherwise.

indicators.name: fragmented_excursion_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count single-entry topic excursions (visiting a topic for just one entry before switching away). These 'touch and go' patterns indicate scattered attention. Each such excursion counts as 1.

indicators.name: work_pressure_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or visits explicitly related to work stress, deadlines, burnout, stress management, or anxiety (e.g., 'deadline', 'burnout', 'stress relief'). Each relevant entry counts as 1.

indicators.name: parallel_work_streams
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the number of distinct work-related topic clusters addressed in this day (e.g., 'cryptography project', 'Haskell learning', 'debugging issue' as 3 separate streams). Count distinct work topics.

indicators.name: social_platform_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to social platforms: Reddit, Twitter/X, Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Hacker News, or discussion forums. Each [visit] to a social site counts as 1.

indicators.name: people_lookup_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches looking up specific people by name, or visits to individual LinkedIn/social profiles. Each person-related lookup counts as 1.

indicators.name: habitual_distraction_sites
indicators.how_to_measure: Count how many distinct distraction domains (e.g., reddit.com, youtube.com, twitter.com) appear on at least 4 different days within this week. These represent ingrained habits.

indicators.name: pattern_regularity_score
indicators.how_to_measure: Rate the consistency of distraction patterns across this week on a 0-2 scale: 0 = highly variable (different sites/times each day); 1 = some recurring patterns; 2 = very consistent habits (same sites, similar times of day).

indicators.name: sleep_related_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or visits related to sleep, insomnia, tiredness, sleep tracking, melatonin, or sleep problems. Each relevant entry counts as 1.

indicators.name: unusual_hours_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if there is browsing activity before 6am or after midnight in this day's data (indicating unusual sleep schedule). 0 if all activity falls within 6am-midnight.

indicators.name: interruption_pattern_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances where a focused topic sequence is suddenly interrupted by an unrelated single action before returning to the original topic. These suggest external notification triggers. Each interruption counts as 1.

indicators.name: messaging_email_checks
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to email (Gmail, Outlook), messaging platforms (Slack, Discord), or communication tools. Each relevant visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: domain_diversity_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the number of distinct website domains visited within this hour. Extract the domain from each [visit] URL and count unique domains.

indicators.name: distraction_site_present
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if any known distraction sites (Reddit, YouTube, social media, news aggregators, entertainment sites) are visited this hour. 0 if only work-focused sites visited.

indicators.name: repeated_search_attempts
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances of multiple similar searches on the same problem with different wording (e.g., 'haskell monad error' then 'haskell monad tutorial' then 'monad example'). Each retry beyond the first counts as 1.

indicators.name: help_resource_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to help resources: Stack Overflow, official documentation, tutorials, API references, or 'how to' guides. Each relevant visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: intrinsic_interest_rating
indicators.how_to_measure: Rate apparent intrinsic interest for this hour on a 0-2 scale: 0 = clearly obligatory/routine work; 1 = neutral tasks; 2 = passionate personal exploration (visible through depth, hobby topics, enthusiastic learning).

indicators.name: personal_interest_content
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if browsing this hour includes clearly personally interesting content (travel planning, hobbies, music exploration, topics explored with visible depth/enthusiasm). 0 if all content appears work-obligatory.

indicators.name: deadline_urgency_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches or visits related to deadlines, calendars, scheduling, time-sensitive queries, or urgency indicators. Each relevant entry counts as 1.

indicators.name: off_hours_work_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Binary: 1 if there is clearly work-related browsing outside typical hours (before 8am, after 7pm, or on weekends), suggesting deadline pressure. 0 if work activity stays within normal hours.
